Date and Place of birth: c. 255 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Feast day 16 January. Banished from Rome under Maxentius (309).
Greek. Feast day 17 August. Banished by the emperor Maxentius, and died in exile.

Roman Berber. Feast day 10 January. First pope after the end of the persecution of Christians through the Edict of Milan (313 AD) issued by Constantine the Great. Presided over the Lateran council of 313.

Date and Place of birth: c. 285 AD Fanum Sancti Angeli de Scala, Apulia et Calabria, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Feast day 31 December. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 2 January. Pope during the First Council of Nicaea (325), the first ecumenical council. Under him was built: the Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran, Santa Croce in Gerusalemme and Old St. Peter's Basilica. Stated to be the recipient of the Donation of Constantine, which was later shown to be a forgery.

Date and Place of birth: c. 290 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. One of Mark's undertakings was to compile stories of the lives of martyrs and bishops before his time. There is some reason to believe he founded two churches in the area of Rome. One of them is still known to this day as the Church of San Marco, although it is greatly changed since his time. The other church was at the Catacomb of Balbina, a cemetery. Emperor Constantine gave gifts of land and furnishing for both buildings. Feast day 7 October.

Date and Place of birth: c. 280 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. He was involved in the Arian controversy, supporting Athanasius of Alexandria.

Date and Place of birth: c. 310 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Banished by the Arian-leaning Emperor Constantius II and later yielding to him. Earliest pope not canonized by the Latin Church. Revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 27 August.[12]

Date and Place of birth: c. 300 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. In opposition to Pope Liberius. Installed by Arian-leaning Emperor Constantius II.

Date and Place of birth: c. 305 AD Egitania, Lusitania or Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. The first pope from modern-day Portugal. Patron of Jerome, commissioned the Vulgate translation of the Bible. Pope during the First Council of Constantinople (381), the second ecumenical council. Council of Rome (382). First pope to be the official head of the church after the Emperor Gratian abdicates the title of "Pontifex Maximus".
Roman. In opposition to Damasus I. Banished to Gallia by Emperor Valentinian II after a war between two sects and died after 384.

Date and Place of birth: c. 334 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. His famous letters—the earliest surviving texts of papal decretals—focus particularly on religious discipline and include decisions on baptism, consecration, ordination, penance, and continence. Siricius’ important decretal of 386 (written to Bishop Himerius of Tarragona), commanding celibacy for priests, was the first decree on this subject.[13]

Date and Place of birth: c. 340 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Instructed priests to stand and bow their heads as they read from the Gospels.
